item.title: CSTR Simulation Model Development
item.description:
Tags:
Associated Backlinks: Kinetics and Thermodynamics

Notes:




Model development, challenges, and refinements made to create a working model. Literature was consulted to validate equilibrium constants, reaction kinetics, and binary interaction parameters.



Components:



Because of the strong non-ideal behavior of the system, the ELECNRTL (Electrolyte Non-Random Two Liquid) model was used. This allows ASPEN to handle ionized species and strong hydrogen bonding interactions present in urea synthesis and side reactions.
Binary interaction parameters for the ammonia-carbon dioxide-water system were confirmed against literature. Studies such as Lemkowitz et al. (1980) and Mac Dowell et al. (2011) detail the phase equilibria of this system, and suggest that strong deviations from ideal behavior should be accounted for Henry‚Äôs Law Components

These are the reactions expected to be in a Urea synthesis process:


This reaction was initially modeled as kinetic but later changed to equilibrium due to literature findings.


Used a power-law kinetic model was used, with activation energy E = 60.93 kJ/mol and pre-exponential factor A = 4.259 √ó 10‚Åµ min‚Åª¬π based on Mahalik et al. (2010).


The reaction order was taken from Park et al. (2009), which suggested a reaction order of 2 with respect to urea.


This reaction was problematic due to mass balance errors, and had to remove. Also assuming this to be negligible due to excess NH3 and CO2, which limits this reaction.


This reaction was added to account for solid byproduct formation. This became problematic if water was included in the feed, as the three inputs would result in salt formation before the reactor. Pure CO2 liquid NH3 were used as feed stocks



The molecular weight of Carbamate Ion (NH‚ÇÇCOO‚Åª) was initially set incorrectly at 78.07 g/mol, but the correct value 60.03 g/mol (ASPEN mistakenly added an NH4, assuming the salt form) resolved balance issues.

Adjustments were made to equilibrium coefficients (Keq) for ammonium carbamate formation using values from Mahmud et al. (2018) . 4.1.2 Physical properties
Physical property calculations for the ELECNRTL model requires a solvent, however inclusion of water with the ammonia feed resulted in salt formation before the reactor, so it was removed

Based on Hamidipour et al. (2005), the reactor was modeled as 10 CSTRs in series, spreading the reactions across different CSTRs and varying the residence times. It is suggested that a multiple-CSTR arrangement is closer to a real plug flow reactor with sieve trays to prevent back mixing, with each CSTR representing a sieve tray. Per Hamidipour et al. the ideal number of sieve trays is 10.



Reaction Rate Differences:

Ammonium carbamate formation is very fast and reaches equilibrium immediately.
Urea formation is slower, requiring a longer residence time.
Biuret formation is even slower and requires long exposure to high temperatures.

Temperature and Pressure Variations:

Ammonium carbamate formation occurs at high pressures and is exothermic.
Urea formation requires lower pressure and higher residence time to achieve sufficient conversion.
Biuret formation happens when urea is at high temperatures for too long.

Controlling Byproduct Formation:

Excessive residence time in the early stages increases undesired biuret formation.





Varying residence times per reactor: Equal residence times were assigned to all reactors, however literature indicates that early reactions were faster than later ones, leading to a near linear increase in residence time across all CSTRs.
Pressure drop across reactors 
Specify reactor volumes instead of residence times


Stoichiometry errors can be fixed by checking molecular weights, and ensuring charge/mole balance.
Use NIST databases for pure/binary component data, and have no estimations made by aspen. Safe to estimate Keq for equilibrium reactions

Wang et al. (2011). Kinetics of the Reversible Reaction of CO‚ÇÇ with Ammonia in aqueous solution
Mahalik et al. (2010). Kinetic studies on hydrolysis of urea in a semi-batch reactor at atmospheric pressure for safe use of ammonia in a power plant for flue gas conditioning
Park et al. (2009). Catalytic conversion of urea to biuret: A catalyst screening study
Mahmud et al. (2018). Carbamate Formation and Amine Protonation Constants in 2-Amino-1-Butanol‚ÄìCO2‚ÄìH2O System and Their Temperature Dependence

item.title: Economic Analysis
item.description:
Tags:
Associated Backlinks: UREA 51 Project Overview

Notes:
A preliminary economic analysis has been conducted for the urea plant with 1.0 MMTPY capacity, focusing on capital costs, operating costs, and profitability metrics. Table 3 summarizes the estimated costs and economic indicators. These estimates assume a grassroot plant co-located with an ammonia production unit (CO‚ÇÇ supplied from ammonia process and ammonia feed available on-site). All costs are in USD (2025 dollars).

Table 3: Estimated economic figures for the 1.0 MMTPY urea plant.
Capital Costs: The high-pressure synthesis loop equipment (reactor, stripper, condenser, high-pressure pumps) are major cost items due to thick walls, exotic metallurgy, and high-pressure accessories. For example, the HP reactor and stripper each can cost tens of millions of dollars (large stainless steel pressure vessels). The CO‚ÇÇ compressor and NH‚ÇÉ pumps, large absorbers, and vacuum systems add significant cost. The prilling tower (being a large civil structure with bucket elevators, etc.) also contributes. Factoring in off-sites and infrastructure, the total installed cost for the urea section is on the order of $300‚Äì$400 million. If the project includes an ammonia plant (to supply NH‚ÇÉ), that adds $700+ million, bringing the integrated complex to around $1+ billion. However, many urea projects assume ammonia is available or use existing ammonia feed; here we consider an integrated case for full scope.
Operating Costs: The largest operating cost is ammonia feedstock. If ammonia is purchased, at current prices (~$350/ton NH‚ÇÉ), the feed cost per ton of urea is significant (about 0.58 tons NH‚ÇÉ per ton urea produced, so $203/ton urea in ammonia cost). In an integrated facility, the cost of ammonia comes from natural gas: roughly 30 GJ per ton NH‚ÇÉ. At $5/MMBtu, that‚Äôs $5* (30/1.055) ‚âà $142 per ton NH‚ÇÉ, so ammonia feed costs $80/ton urea. CO‚ÇÇ feed is often a byproduct and can be considered free or low cost (just compression power). Utilities include steam (some steam is generated by the process itself in the carbamate condenser, reducing net steam import). Steam consumption for concentration and stripping might be ~0.8 ton steam per ton urea (some medium pressure, some low). Power for compressors/pumps is also significant: the CO‚ÇÇ compressor might consume ~8 MW, and various pumps maybe 1‚Äì2 MW. Cooling water and instrument air, etc., are minor contributors. We estimate cash operating cost around $100‚Äì$120/ton for an integrated plant (excluding ammonia production capital) (A boost for agriculture from SA | Baker Young), which is in the lowest quartile globally for urea production cost. This is consistent with a modern large-scale plant achieving economies of scale. If ammonia must be bought, operating cost would rise to $200+ per ton as shown.
Profitability: At a urea price of $300/ton (which has fluctuated widely; it can be $250‚Äì$400 depending on global markets), the gross margin is healthy. The IRR for the project is expected to be in the 20‚Äì30% range (A boost for agriculture from SA | Baker Young) if the plant operates at capacity and feed gas is cheap. For instance, a recent integrated 1 mtpa urea project reported an IRR of ~30% with low-cost gas and operating costs of $109/ton (A boost for agriculture from SA | Baker Young). Our more conservative case yields ~20% IRR, which is still attractive. The NPV over 20 years (10% discount) is strongly positive (on the order of $0.5 billion), and the payback period (time to recoup investment from net cash flow) is about 4‚Äì5 years. These metrics indicate the project is economically feasible. We will conduct sensitivity analysis below to test robustness against price swings.
In Aspen Plus, an economic evaluation tool or spreadsheet can be linked to the model to compute these figures from material and energy balances. For example, the model output provides duties (for estimating energy costs) and flow rates (for feedstock costs). Equipment sizing (from Aspen Economic Analyzer or manual sizing) can be used for capital cost estimates via cost correlations or vendor quotes. We have used a factored estimate approach (Lang factors) for this preliminary analysis.

item.title: Energy Integration and Optimization
item.description:
Tags:
Associated Backlinks: UREA 51 Project Overview

Notes:
The Snamprogetti process already incorporates significant heat integration by design ‚Äì this is reflected in the Aspen model and further optimizations are explored:

Heat Recovery from Condensation: The exothermic condensation of carbamate in the HP condenser is used to generate low-pressure steam () (). In our model, we ensure that this duty is captured: the heat released (on the order of 10^7 kcal/hr) is applied to boil water at 4.5 bar. This steam is then available to be used in the low-pressure decomposer or elsewhere, reducing boiler load. Any excess heat can be used to preheat boiler feed water or for the ammonia process.

Intermediate Heat Exchangers: The vapor stream from the MP decomposer is used to preheat the urea solution entering the vacuum section. We included a preheater (E-1403) where the hot 18-bar vapor (~150¬∞C) heats the 62% urea solution (which might be ~100¬∞C after flashing to near vacuum) up to ~130¬∞C before it enters the vacuum concentrator. This recovers heat that would otherwise be wasted and cuts down steam usage in the vacuum evaporators. Our model shows this saves roughly 20% of low-pressure steam consumption in the evaporation section (consistent with literature improvements).

Steam Level Optimization: We optimized the steam usage by carefully selecting pressure levels for the reboilers. For example, using 4 bar steam in the HP stripper (rather than 10 bar) is possible because of the large temperature driving force (205¬∞C process vs ~150¬∞C steam). Medium-pressure steam (18 bar) is used only where needed (MP decomposer). By cascading steam usage (HP generates LP steam, which is reused in LP sections), the overall energy efficiency improves. The Aspen model energy balance indicates a steam consumption of ~1.6 ton steam per ton urea (before integration), which drops to ~1.1 ton/ton after integration measures ‚Äì a ~30% reduction in external steam demand, aligning with improvements noted in case studies () ().

Reaction Optimization ‚Äì Temperature Profile: An optimal reactor temperature is crucial for maximum conversion at minimum energy. We performed sensitivity runs in Aspen varying reactor temperature. Too low (e.g. 170¬∞C) and urea yield drops, increasing recycle loads (thus more stripping duty). Too high (>190¬∞C) and while urea formation per pass may increase slightly, the heat load on condensation increases and more CO‚ÇÇ remains unconverted (because Reaction 1 equilibrium worsens), also risking biuret formation. The optimum observed in simulation was around 185¬∞C, confirming the chosen design.

NH‚ÇÉ:CO‚ÇÇ Ratio Optimization: Similarly, we varied NH‚ÇÉ:CO‚ÇÇ ratio. A ratio of 4:1 gave only marginally higher conversion than 3.4:1 but at the cost of circulating a lot more ammonia (which increases pumping duty and condenser duty). A ratio too low (2.5:1) drastically reduced conversion (to ~45%) (Urea51_Thermodynamics and Kinetics_SupplementalReport.pdf), which would require much larger recycle equipment. Thus ~3.3:1 is optimal for balancing conversion and energy. This aligns with Snamprogetti‚Äôs recommended range (). The model confirms that beyond 3.6:1, diminishing returns are seen.

CO‚ÇÇ Conversion per Pass vs Stages: We looked at whether adding another medium-pressure decomposition stage (or increasing residence) could improve efficiency. The base case already gets ~99% overall conversion with two stages (MP and LP). Adding a third very low pressure scrubber to capture the last ppm of NH‚ÇÉ/CO‚ÇÇ would have high cost for little gain (since emissions are already controlled). We found that routing the LP off-gas to the existing MP absorber and then a final water scrubber is sufficient for essentially zero ammonia emission.

Power Recovery: While not in the base design, an idea is to use the pressure letdown of carbamate solution (150 ‚Üí 18 bar) to drive a turbo-expander and recover some mechanical work. However, the presence of a flashing multi-component mixture and risk of solid formation make this challenging. Instead, the design uses an ejector where high-pressure ammonia is expanded to suck carbamate solution (this mixes streams but saves a pump) (). The Aspen model can simulate an ejector qualitatively (via energy balance), but we have not included a turbo-expander due to complexity; however, the potential energy recovery is noted for future improvement (~2‚Äì3 MW could be recovered theoretically).

Overall, through these optimizations, the plant‚Äôs energy consumption (as modeled by Aspen) is roughly 6.0 Gcal/ton urea (including ammonia synthesis energy, if integrated). Isolating the urea section, the thermal energy use (steam) is on the order of 1.0‚Äì1.2 Gcal/ton, and electrical energy ~50 kWh/ton. These are in line with modern urea plant benchmarks. Heat integration ensures much of the energy from exothermic reactions is reused within the process, thereby reducing CO‚ÇÇ emissions associated with steam generation.
CO‚ÇÇ Emissions: Urea production is unique in that it consumes CO‚ÇÇ as a raw material. For every ton of urea (CO(NH‚ÇÇ)‚ÇÇ, 0.73 ton CO‚ÇÇ is theoretically required stoichiometrically). In our process, essentially all feed CO‚ÇÇ is converted to urea, so direct CO‚ÇÇ process emissions are near-zero (any small vented CO‚ÇÇ is from incomplete recovery, which we‚Äôve minimized via absorption). However, the indirect CO‚ÇÇ emissions depend on ammonia sourcing: conventional ammonia production from natural gas emits ~1.6 tons CO‚ÇÇ per ton NH‚ÇÉ, which for 0.58 ton NH‚ÇÉ/ton urea means ~0.93 ton CO‚ÇÇ/ton urea produced (and that CO‚ÇÇ is exactly what we feed into urea). If the ammonia-urea complex is self-contained, the CO‚ÇÇ byproduct from ammonia is fully utilized in urea ‚Äì effectively carbon capture and utilization (CCU). The CO‚ÇÇ ends up in the urea product, which when applied as fertilizer, will eventually release CO‚ÇÇ back to the atmosphere (urea decomposes in soil to CO‚ÇÇ and ammonia). So the net carbon footprint is tied to ammonia production. To align with Sustainable Development Goals and climate initiatives, the plant could integrate carbon capture for any excess CO‚ÇÇ and consider green ammonia (from electrolysis) to eliminate fossil CO‚ÇÇ. Our design supports such future improvements: e.g., if CO‚ÇÇ from ammonia is insufficient or too much, we can take additional captured CO‚ÇÇ from other processes. The Leigh Creek project in Australia (similar scale) aims for carbon-neutral urea by CCS and renewables (A boost for agriculture from SA | Baker Young) (A boost for agriculture from SA | Baker Young) ‚Äì an approach this design can adopt with minor modifications (mostly upstream of CO‚ÇÇ feed).

item.description:
Tags:

import numpy as np import matplotlib.pyplot as plt # Constants R = 8.314 # J/(mol*K) - Universal gas constant T_range = np.linspace(400, 500, 50) # Temperature range from 400K to 500K A_phi = 1.27 # Debye-H√ºckel parameter rho = 1.5 # Ion correlation parameter I_x0 = 0.1 # Reference ionic strength # Define species in the NH3-CO2-H2O System (without Urea) species = { "NH3": {"charge": 0, "mole_fraction": 0.455}, "CO2": {"charge": 0, "mole_fraction": 0.152}, "H2O": {"charge": 0, "mole_fraction": 0.076}, "NH4+": {"charge": 1, "mole_fraction": 0.023}, "NH2COO-": {"charge": -1, "mole_fraction": 0.061}, "HCO3-": {"charge": -1, "mole_fraction": 0.015} } # Binary Interaction Parameters (From Table 6 in the Paper) interaction_params = { ("H2O", "NH3"): {"tau_1": 0.5275, "tau_2": -1022.3, "alpha": 0.1}, ("NH3", "H2O"): {"tau_1": 3.0173, "tau_2": -726.72, "alpha": 0.1}, ("H2O", "NH4+"): {"tau_1": -3.9505, "tau_2": 2860.2, "alpha": 0.2}, ("NH4+", "H2O"): {"tau_1": 3.4774, "tau_2": -1850.6, "alpha": 0.2}, ("H2O", "NH2COO-"): {"tau_1": 9.7292, "tau_2": 0.0, "alpha": 0.2}, ("NH2COO-", "H2O"): {"tau_1": -4.3814, "tau_2": 0.0, "alpha": 0.2}, ("NH4+", "NH2COO-"): {"tau_1": 7.3696, "tau_2": 0.0, "alpha": 0.1}, ("NH2COO-", "NH4+"): {"tau_1": -4.8826, "tau_2": 0.0, "alpha": 0.1}, } # Function to compute ionic strength def compute_ionic_strength(species): return 0.5 * sum(s["charge"]**2 * s["mole_fraction"] for s in species.values()) # Electrolyte NRTL binary interaction function def electrolyte_nrtl_binary_interaction(T, tau_1, tau_2): """Temperature-dependent binary interaction parameters using Gibbs-Helmholtz equation.""" return tau_1 + (tau_2 / T) # Store results for plotting gamma_values = {name: [] for name in species.keys()} # Loop over temperature range for T in T_range: I_x = compute_ionic_strength(species) # Long-Range Contribution (Debye-H√ºckel Term) G_ex_PDH = (-4 * A_phi * I_x / rho) * np.log((1 + rho * np.sqrt(I_x)) / (1 + rho * np.sqrt(I_x0))) G_ex_PDH *= sum(species[name]["mole_fraction"] for name in species) * R * T # Short-Range Contribution (Local Composition Model - Electrolyte NRTL) G_ex_lc = sum( electrolyte_nrtl_binary_interaction(T, params["tau_1"], params["tau_2"]) * sum(species[name]["mole_fraction"] for name in species) * R * T for params in interaction_params.values() ) # Compute Activity Coefficients gamma_i = { name: np.exp(-A_phi * ((2 * s["charge"]**2 / rho) * np.log((1 + rho * np.sqrt(I_x)) / (1 + rho * np.sqrt(I_x0))))) for name, s in species.items() } # Store values for plotting for name in gamma_values.keys(): gamma_values[name].append(gamma_i[name]) # Plot Activity Coefficients vs Temperature plt.figure(figsize=(10, 6)) for name, gamma_list in gamma_values.items(): plt.plot(T_range, gamma_list, label=name) plt.xlabel("Temperature (K)") plt.ylabel("Activity Coefficient (Œ≥)") plt.title("Activity Coefficients in Electrolyte NRTL Model (NH3-CO2-H2O System)") plt.legend() plt.grid() plt.show() Run

item.description:
Tags:
Associated Backlinks: UREA 51 Project Overview

Notes:
This urea plant is designed to meet or exceed environmental regulations and contribute to sustainable development goals (SDGs) wherever possible:

Minimal Emissions and Effluents: The process is essentially a closed-loop for NH‚ÇÉ and CO‚ÇÇ, so air emissions are very low. The only routine emissions are from the prilling tower vent (containing trace ammonia and urea dust) and a small inert purge. We have included a prill tower scrubber ‚Äì a water scrubber that captures >90% of ammonia and dust from the exhaust. This ensures ammonia in the off-gas is <50 mg/Nm¬≥, meeting strict air quality standards. The scrubbing water, now containing ammonium carbamate, is returned to the process (to the LP absorber) so the ammonia isn‚Äôt wasted. Wastewater from the plant (condensate from vacuum and scrubbers) is treated in the hydrolyzer/stripper unit to decompose dissolved urea and remove ammonia (). The final process water has <10 ppm urea and <1 ppm NH‚ÇÉ, which is suitable for discharge or reuse as boiler feedwater. These measures protect water bodies from eutrophication (aligning with SDG 6: Clean Water) and minimize air pollution (SDG 15: Life on Land, due to preventing ammonia emissions that could cause acidification).

CO‚ÇÇ Utilization and Climate Impact: The plant captures CO‚ÇÇ (from ammonia production or other sources) and converts it into urea, effectively sequestering it in solid form for some time. While eventually the carbon in urea returns to the atmosphere when urea is used, this process is a form of carbon utilization that can be coupled with carbon capture initiatives. By integrating the urea plant with an ammonia plant that uses natural gas, we utilize the CO‚ÇÇ that would otherwise be vented. If green ammonia (produced from renewable energy and water electrolysis) is used along with captured CO‚ÇÇ from the air or industrial flue gases, this urea production could be carbon-neutral or even carbon-negative (if urea is used in ways that lock the carbon). This supports SDG 13: Climate Action by reducing net greenhouse gas emissions relative to business-as-usual fertilizer production. Our design can accommodate a CO‚ÇÇ feed from a carbon capture unit, and we have allowed for adding a CO‚ÇÇ purification unit if CO‚ÇÇ comes from a flue gas (removing O‚ÇÇ, impurities before compression).

Energy Efficiency and SDG 7: Through heat integration and modern efficient equipment, the energy consumption per ton of urea is minimized. Efficient energy use contributes to SDG 7: Affordable and Clean Energy by lowering the fuel required (hence lower CO‚ÇÇ emissions and cost). For instance, generating steam within the process and recovering low-grade heat reflects responsible consumption of energy (SDG 12). We also considered renewable integration: e.g., using solar heat for preheating boiler feedwater, or powering some compressors with renewable electricity, which can further cut carbon footprint. The Leigh Creek case study showed that with a comprehensive strategy (renewables, CCS), even a large urea project can target carbon neutrality (A boost for agriculture from SA | Baker Young), which we take as inspiration.

Safety and Regulatory Compliance: Urea plants deal with toxic ammonia and high pressures. Our model and design adhere to safety standards (ASME codes for pressure vessels, etc.). Although safety is not explicitly an SDG, it is part of sustainable industrialization (SDG 9). We ensure all high-pressure equipment has proper relief systems routed to a flare or scrubber. The process control strategy includes alarms and interlocks to prevent releases. By preventing accidents (which could cause environmental damage), we support overall sustainability.

Product Stewardship: Urea fertilizer, if overused, can cause nutrient runoff. While that is beyond the plant‚Äôs direct control, companies are increasingly responsible for end-to-end impact. As part of sustainable practices, the urea product could be coated or formulated to be controlled-release, improving nitrogen use efficiency on farms (reducing N‚ÇÇO emissions and runoff). Our plant could produce such enhanced-efficiency fertilizers with minor tweaks in the finishing section (e.g., adding a coating unit after prilling). This aligns with SDG 2 (Zero Hunger, via better fertilizer use) and SDG 12 (Responsible Consumption, by reducing environmental impact of fertilizer use).
In summary, the Aspen Plus model is not only set up to achieve production and economic goals, but also to ensure environmental compliance is built-in. Emission points are identified and mitigated in the simulation (e.g., all NH‚ÇÉ vent streams are routed to absorption). The model tracks all nitrogen and carbon, confirming that nearly all ends up in the product or is recycled. This closed-loop approach means virtually no uncontrolled emissions. The design is consistent with environmental regulations such as EPA standards for ammonia ( < 3 ppm in water, < 100 ppm in air from vents) and international best practices for urea plants. By integrating energy efficiency and emission controls, the urea process contributes to sustainable industrial development while meeting the global demand for fertilizers in an eco-friendly manner.

Below are the recommended EOS choices for each unit operation, along with the basis for their selection:


Recommended EOS: Peng-Robinson (PR) EOS Basis for Selection:

The urea synthesis reaction occurs at high pressure (130-250 bar) and involves a non-ideal liquid phase.
PR EOS provides reasonable accuracy for phase equilibrium calculations involving CO‚ÇÇ, NH‚ÇÉ, and carbamate species.
It is widely used for modeling gas-liquid equilibria and supercritical conditions‚Äã.


Recommended EOS: Ideal Gas Law / Peng-Robinson EOS Basis for Selection:

At lower pressures and moderate temperatures, CO‚ÇÇ behaves as an ideal gas, allowing the use of the Ideal Gas Law.
However, at higher pressures, CO‚ÇÇ exhibits significant non-ideal behavior, making PR EOS more appropriate‚Äã.


Recommended EOS: Soave-Redlich-Kwong (SRK) EOS Basis for Selection:

The NH‚ÇÉ and CO‚ÇÇ mixture is highly non-ideal, requiring a cubic EOS like SRK.
SRK provides good predictions for gas-phase behavior at high pressures and moderate temperatures‚Äã.


Recommended EOS: Ideal Gas Law / PR EOS (for high-pressure systems) Basis for Selection:

If the system involves gases at moderate pressures, the Ideal Gas Law can be used.
If dealing with high-pressure conditions where CO‚ÇÇ liquefies, PR EOS provides better accuracy‚Äã.


Recommended EOS: Peng-Robinson EOS Basis for Selection:

Since NH‚ÇÉ and CO‚ÇÇ interact strongly in the liquid phase, PR EOS is a better choice for modeling condensation behavior.
It provides accurate predictions of vapor-liquid equilibrium (VLE)‚Äã.


Recommended EOS: Peng-Robinson EOS Basis for Selection:

These units experience phase separation as pressure decreases.
PR EOS is reliable for predicting phase behavior and decompression effects‚Äã.


Recommended EOS: Antoine Equation (for vapor pressure) & PR EOS Basis for Selection:

The Antoine Equation is useful for calculating vapor pressure of NH‚ÇÉ and CO‚ÇÇ.

Recommended EOS: Incompressible Liquid Model Basis for Selection:

Pumps handle primarily liquid NH‚ÇÉ, CO‚ÇÇ, and carbamate, which are nearly incompressible.
A simple incompressible liquid model (constant density) is sufficient.

The prilling process involves cooling liquid urea to solid form.
Solid-liquid phase transition models and heat transfer equations are used instead of EOS.

item.description:
Tags:
Associated Backlinks: UREA 51 Project Overview

Notes:
The Snamprogetti (Saipem) ammonia stripping process is a leading technology for urea production. This model targets 1.0 million US tons per year of granular urea (approximately 907,000 metric tons/year), which equates to about 113,000 kg/hr of urea product at 8000 operating hours/year. The feedstocks are anhydrous ammonia and carbon dioxide, with approximate fresh feed rates of 69,000 kg/hr NH‚ÇÉ and 83,000 kg/hr CO‚ÇÇ, assuming minimal losses (these values will be refined via recycle in the model). Urea is produced by the reaction of ammonia and carbon dioxide in a high-pressure synthesis loop, followed by recovery and purification steps to yield 99.6 wt% purity molten urea, which is solidified into prills. Table 1 summarizes the key design basis parameters for the Aspen Plus model.

(Engineers Guide: The Snamprogetti Urea Process Description) (Engineers Guide: The Snamprogetti Urea Process Description) Figure 1: Simplified process flow diagram for the Snamprogetti urea synthesis process. The high-pressure reactor and stripper (left) convert NH‚ÇÉ and CO‚ÇÇ to urea and carbamate, while medium and low-pressure decomposers and evaporators (right) remove water and recover unreacted NH‚ÇÉ/CO‚ÇÇ. The final concentrated melt is solidified in a prilling tower.
The Snamprogetti process employs total recycle with ammonia stripping: excess ammonia in the reactor effluent serves as a self-stripping agent to remove CO‚ÇÇ and carbamate in a high-pressure stripper (Engineers Guide: The Snamprogetti Urea Process Description) (Engineers Guide: The Snamprogetti Urea Process Description). Recovered CO‚ÇÇ and NH‚ÇÉ are condensed back to ammonium carbamate and recycled to the reactor at high pressure, achieving about 80% conversion of CO‚ÇÇ in the high-pressure loop (Engineers Guide: The Snamprogetti Urea Process Description). This minimizes the load on downstream recovery and reduces the need for high-pressure pumping of recycle streams. The Aspen Plus model will rigorously simulate each section of the process ‚Äì high-pressure synthesis, medium/low-pressure purification, and finishing ‚Äì with detailed unit operation models, operating conditions, reaction kinetics, and recycle loops to meet the production target.

Global Urea Market

Project Scope

Agriculture
‚Ä¢ Urea as a Fertilizer: Urea is the most widely used nitrogen-based fertilizer, essential for crop growth and soil nitrogen management (Kumar, 2015).
‚Ä¢ Nitrous Oxide Emissions Concern: While effective, urea application significantly increases greenhouse gas emissions, particularly nitrous oxide (N‚ÇÇO), a major environmental concern (Jiang et al., 2024).
‚Ä¢ Sustainable Practices with Green Urea: Innovations like slow-release and nano-based coatings (Green Urea) improve efficiency and reduce environmental impact (Yahya, 2018).
Medicine
‚Ä¢ Urea in Skincare and Dermatology: Urea is widely used in topical creams to treat dry skin, eczema, and psoriasis due to its moisturizing and keratolytic properties (Mohapatra et al., 2019).
‚Ä¢ Diuretics and Kidney Function Monitoring: Urea plays a crucial role in diuretic drugs that help patients with fluid retention and kidney issues. Urea biosensors are also widely used in medical diagnostics (Gupta et al., 2012).
Automobile Systems
‚Ä¢ Reducing NOx Emissions: Urea is a key component in Selective Catalytic Reduction (SCR) technology used in diesel engines to reduce nitrogen oxide (NOx) emissions (Mohapatra et al., 2019).
‚Ä¢ Sustainability in Vehicle Emission Control: Urea-based exhaust treatments significantly improve air quality by breaking down harmful gases into nitrogen and water (Ammar et al., 2024).
Laboratory Applications
‚Ä¢ Protein Denaturation & Biochemical Research: Urea is used as a denaturant in protein studies, helping scientists understand protein structure and folding (Gupta et al., 2010).
‚Ä¢ Medical Imaging & Diagnostic Testing: Urea is critical in laboratory tests for renal function, and its use in biosensors enables rapid medical diagnostics (Mohapatra et al., 2019).

item.title: Process Control Strategy for Stable Operation
item.description:
Tags:
Associated Backlinks: UREA 51 Project Overview

Notes:
Designing a robust control strategy is crucial given the tightly integrated recycle loops and high pressures in this urea plant. The Aspen Plus model is steady-state, but we specify controller setpoints and strategies that would be used in operation (and could be tested in Aspen Dynamics). Key control loops and strategies, informed by best practices in process control (Process Dynamics and Control (Dale E. Seborg, Thomas F. Edgar etc.) (Z-Library).pdf) (Process Dynamics and Control (Dale E. Seborg, Thomas F. Edgar etc.) (Z-Library).pdf) and the dynamics of recycle systems, include:

Reactor Pressure Control: The reactor/HP loop pressure (~150 bar) must be maintained to keep reaction equilibrium. A pressure controller (PIC) monitors reactor pressure and manipulates a downstream valve or vent. To avoid ‚Äúsnowball‚Äù effects in the recycle (Process Dynamics and Control (Dale E. Seborg, Thomas F. Edgar etc.) (Z-Library).pdf) (Process Dynamics and Control (Dale E. Seborg, Thomas F. Edgar etc.) (Z-Library).pdf), it is preferable to manipulate an exit stream rather than a feed. Thus, a small inert vent from the HP condenser is used: if pressure rises above setpoint, the vent valve opens slightly to release inert gases (and some NH‚ÇÉ/CO‚ÇÇ) to a scrubber, bringing pressure down. Major deviations are rare since feeds are mostly liquid, but this ensures safe pressure. The fresh feed flow controllers (for NH‚ÇÉ pump and CO‚ÇÇ compressor) typically run at set ratio (see below) and could trim flows for slow pressure control if needed (cascade from PIC to CO‚ÇÇ feed if venting capacity is limited).

NH‚ÇÉ/CO‚ÇÇ Feed Ratio Control: Maintaining the correct ammonia to carbon dioxide ratio (~3.4:1 molar) is critical for conversion and to avoid ammonium carbamate precipitation (if NH‚ÇÉ too low) or excess free ammonia (if too high). A ratio controller is implemented: the NH‚ÇÉ feed flow is controlled in cascade to a flow controller on the CO‚ÇÇ feed or vice versa. For example, measure CO‚ÇÇ feed flow (master) and adjust NH‚ÇÉ feed to maintain the desired ratio (Process Dynamics and Control (Dale E. Seborg, Thomas F. Edgar etc.) (Z-Library).pdf) (Process Dynamics and Control (Dale E. Seborg, Thomas F. Edgar etc.) (Z-Library).pdf). Alternatively, a ratio station can set the NH‚ÇÉ flow setpoint as 3.4 * CO‚ÇÇ flow. This ensures even if CO‚ÇÇ feed fluctuates, ammonia feed follows proportionally, keeping the reactor inlet composition stable. Ratio control is a simple form of feedforward control that greatly stabilizes the key reactant proportion (Process Dynamics and Control (Dale E. Seborg, Thomas F. Edgar etc.) (Z-Library).pdf) (Process Dynamics and Control (Dale E. Seborg, Thomas F. Edgar etc.) (Z-Library).pdf).

Reactor Temperature Control: The reactor is mostly adiabatic, so temperature is a function of feed conditions and reaction extent. There is no direct jacket on the reactor in this design (unlike a catalytic reactor), but temperature can be indirectly controlled by adjusting the NH‚ÇÉ recycle or feed temperature. For instance, the ammonia preheater bypass can be used: if reactor temperature is too low (perhaps due to less reaction heat), one can increase feed NH‚ÇÉ temperature (within metallurgical limits) by routing more through the preheater. Conversely, if reactor temperature is trending high, slightly cooler feed helps absorb heat. This is a slow control loop. A more direct approach is to monitor reactor temperature and ensure it stays below ~190¬∞C by adjusting the steam rate in the stripper (since the stripper reboiler duty can indirectly influence reactor temperature by shifting equilibrium). This leads to‚Ä¶

Stripper Heating Control (Cascade): The HP stripper duty is adjusted to maintain a target bottom temperature or urea concentration. A temperature controller on the stripper outlet (or a composition analyzer for urea in solution) manipulates the steam flow to the stripper reboiler. This is implemented as a cascade control: the master controller (urea concentration or bottom temp, TIC) sets the setpoint for a flow controller on steam (FIC). The flow controller then quickly adjusts the steam valve. This cascade improves response because the steam flow can be adjusted rapidly to disturbances, while the temperature loop takes care of the slower concentration dynamics (Process Dynamics and Control (Dale E. Seborg, Thomas F. Edgar etc.) (Z-Library).pdf) (Process Dynamics and Control (Dale E. Seborg, Thomas F. Edgar etc.) (Z-Library).pdf). The goal is to ensure consistent decomposition of carbamate so that the downstream load is steady. If the stripper temp rises too high, the TIC will cut back steam to avoid excessive stripping (which could overheat and also flood the condenser with too much gas).

Level Control (HP Loop): The high-pressure carbamate condenser/receiver has a liquid level (carbamate recycle). A level controller (LIC) here manipulates the recycle pump or a letdown valve to the MP section. Usually, the carbamate recycle pump draws off liquid at a fixed rate; if the level rises, a small amount of carbamate solution can be let down to the MP absorber suction (some designs include a letdown for excess). In Aspen, we ensure the recycle loop has a degree of freedom by specifying one stream flow via a design spec to maintain overall mass balance. Similarly, the stripper bottom level is controlled by the letdown valve to the MP decomposer (XV-1101). The LIC at the stripper opens/closes this valve to maintain level, thereby regulating the flow into the MP section () (). This prevents carrying over gas into MP or starving it.

MP Absorber & Recycle Controls: The medium-pressure absorber (carbamate separator column) has its own controls akin to a distillation column. We maintain the pressure at ~18 bar via a backpressure regulator on the vent to the LP scrubber. The reflux ratio (liquid NH‚ÇÉ feed) is set so that essentially all CO‚ÇÇ is absorbed. An overhead condenser may be present (cooler for the top), maintaining a temperature ~45¬∞C; its duty could be adjusted to control overhead vapor temperature (which correlates with NH‚ÇÉ slip). The bottom level of this column (carbamate solution) is controlled by the carbamate recycle pump flow ‚Äì essentially pumping out at the rate that maintains level. A downstream flow controller on P-1201 ensures the exact required recycle rate (12 t/h or as needed). The pure ammonia that collects in the reflux drum (V-1201) is split: some is refluxed to the column, and excess is sent forward to the reactor feed. A level control on the reflux drum typically splits the flow: if the ammonia level rises, more ammonia is sent to the reactor feed. This effectively recycles unconverted ammonia.

Low-Pressure & Vacuum Controls: The low-pressure decomposer has a pressure controller via a vacuum system or control valve maintaining ~4 bar. Steam flow to its reboiler is flow-controlled based on a temperature setpoint to get the desired urea concentration out. The vacuum evaporators operate under tight pressure control via vacuum pumps or steam ejectors; their condensate levels are controlled by condensate pumps. Each evaporator has a temperature control (via steam valve) to hit the target concentration. The final melt tank level is controlled by adjusting the prill tower feed pump speed (ensuring a steady feed to prilling). The prilling tower itself requires control of air flow (to maintain prill cooling rate) and sometimes melt spray rate (to control prill size). These are generally fixed once at steady state, but interlocks exist to shut off melt feed if the air flow fails (to avoid a heap of molten urea).

Safety Interlocks: Though not part of normal control, the high-pressure section has safety systems. High pressure or high temperature trips will shut feeds and vent to safeties. For example, if reactor pressure > design, emergency relief to a scrubber activates. Toxic ammonia detectors around the prill tower or pumps can trigger alarms or water deluge. These aspects aren‚Äôt in the steady-state model but are considered in design.

Control Philosophy: Overall, the plant is run with the high-pressure loop self-regulating via recycle, and more active control on the downstream sections to handle the large swings in flow when feed or production rates change. The recycle loops can cause interaction and long process delays (known as recycle transients or ‚Äúsnowball‚Äù effects). The control strategy avoids manipulating recycle flow directly for control (Process Dynamics and Control (Dale E. Seborg, Thomas F. Edgar etc.) (Z-Library).pdf) (Process Dynamics and Control (Dale E. Seborg, Thomas F. Edgar etc.) (Z-Library).pdf); instead it manipulates utilities or purge streams to absorb disturbances. For example, if the urea production rate is to be increased, both NH‚ÇÉ and CO‚ÇÇ feed setpoints are ramped together (ratio kept constant) and the system gradually finds a new equilibrium; the stripper steam is increased to handle extra load, etc. Advanced strategies like feedforward control can be added: e.g., if CO‚ÇÇ feed rate changes, proactively adjust stripper steam and absorber coolant to anticipate composition changes. Cascade control is applied where a secondary measurement can respond faster (steam flow, etc.) (Process Dynamics and Control (Dale E. Seborg, Thomas F. Edgar etc.) (Z-Library).pdf) (Process Dynamics and Control (Dale E. Seborg, Thomas F. Edgar etc.) (Z-Library).pdf). Critical measurements include reactor temperature, stripper bottom composition, and condensate quality (for environmental compliance).
From the process control literature, this approach of combining ratio control for feeds, cascade temperature control for critical exchangers, and inventory (level/pressure) control for each section is standard for complex chemical plants (Process Dynamics and Control (Dale E. Seborg, Thomas F. Edgar etc.) (Z-Library).pdf) (Process Dynamics and Control (Dale E. Seborg, Thomas F. Edgar etc.) (Z-Library).pdf). The Aspen model will implement these controls conceptually (through specifications or design specs) to ensure the steady-state solution respects operational constraints (e.g., the ratio spec ensures proper convergence of the recycle). By including these control considerations in the design phase, the process model reflects a realistic and operable plant, not just an ideal simulation.

item.title: Process Units and Operating Conditions
item.description:
Tags:
Associated Backlinks: UREA 51 Project Overview

Notes:
1. High-Pressure Synthesis Loop: The heart of the process is the high-pressure synthesis loop, which operates around ~150 bar and 185‚Äì190¬∞C to maximize urea formation (). Key equipment and conditions are:

Ammonia Feed System (P-100 & E-100): Liquid ammonia from storage (‚âà18 bar, 12¬∞C) is pressurized in stages. A booster pump brings NH‚ÇÉ to ~22 bar, then a high-pressure reciprocating pump raises it to ~240 bar (Engineers Guide: The Snamprogetti Urea Process Description) (Engineers Guide: The Snamprogetti Urea Process Description) to ensure ~150 bar at the reactor inlet (allowing for pressure drop). A pulsation damper is included to smooth flow. Ammonia is preheated to ~75¬∞C before the reactor using recovered heat (e.g. from low-pressure condenser vapors) (Engineers Guide: The Snamprogetti Urea Process Description). The fresh NH‚ÇÉ feed rate (after recycle makeup) is ~69 t/hr as noted.

CO‚ÇÇ Feed Compressor (C-101): Gaseous CO‚ÇÇ (e.g. from an ammonia plant‚Äôs reformer) at ~1.5 bar, 40¬∞C is compressed in a multi-stage compressor with intercooling (Engineers Guide: The Snamprogetti Urea Process Description). The discharge is ~150‚Äì160 bar, ~40¬∞C. The CO‚ÇÇ feed (‚âà83 t/hr fresh) is introduced to the high-pressure stripper (described below) rather than directly to the reactor in this ammonia-stripping configuration. Compressed CO‚ÇÇ may be slightly preheated or fed as is, depending on the design.

High-Pressure Reactor (R-101): A vertical, multi-tray reactor (approximately 25‚Äì30 m tall) where NH‚ÇÉ and CO‚ÇÇ react to form urea. Operating conditions are ~150 bar and 185‚Äì190¬∞C (), with an NH‚ÇÉ:CO‚ÇÇ molar ratio ~3.4:1 maintained by excess ammonia (). Under these conditions, about 62‚Äì65% of the CO‚ÇÇ is converted to urea per pass (Engineers Guide: The Snamprogetti Urea Process Description) (the remainder forms ammonium carbamate or remains unreacted). The reactor trays (e.g. ‚Äúsupercup‚Äù trays) enhance mixing and residence time, effectively creating a series of small CSTR zones to approach equilibrium (). Residence time is designed >25 minutes, which is sufficient for the slow carbamate dehydration reaction to approach equilibrium (). The reactor effluent is a liquid solution of ~34‚Äì40 wt% urea in a mixture of ammonium carbamate, unconverted NH‚ÇÉ, CO‚ÇÇ, and water (). A small vapor phase (mostly NH‚ÇÉ and CO‚ÇÇ) may be present at the top. The reactor is typically operated adiabatically or with minimal cooling; the heat of carbamate formation raises the temperature to the equilibrium level (~188¬∞C). High-grade stainless steel (25-22-2 CrNiMo) with titanium/zirconium lining is used due to the corrosive carbamate environment () ().

High-Pressure Stripper (E-102): The hot reactor effluent flows to a falling-film carbamate stripper operating at the same high pressure (~150 bar) (). The stripper is a vertical heat exchanger (often with titanium tubes) where medium-pressure steam (e.g. 4‚Äì7 bar steam) is fed to the shell to heat the urea solution to ~200‚Äì205¬∞C (). This endothermic heating decomposes a large portion of ammonium carbamate back to NH‚ÇÉ and CO‚ÇÇ, which bubbles out and strips additional NH‚ÇÉ/CO‚ÇÇ from the descending liquid () (). In the Snamprogetti process, the stripping agent is predominantly the excess NH‚ÇÉ vapor generated by heating, as well as the CO‚ÇÇ feed itself (introduced at the bottom of the stripper) (Engineers Guide: The Snamprogetti Urea Process Description) (Engineers Guide: The Snamprogetti Urea Process Description). The stripper thus removes most of the unconverted NH‚ÇÉ and CO‚ÇÇ from the solution. The bottom liquid, now concentrated to ~42‚Äì45 wt% urea () (), collects in the stripper sump. A level control is maintained to ensure a liquid seal (preventing gas carry-under). The harsh conditions (up to 205¬∞C, carbamate present) require special metallurgy and historically required periodic equipment rotation/replacement () () (modern materials like Saipem‚Äôs Omegabond‚ìá lining have extended stripper life to >20 years ()).

High-Pressure Carbamate Condenser (E-101): The NH‚ÇÉ and CO‚ÇÇ vapors leaving the stripper (along with any carryover water or urea vapor) flow to the HP carbamate condenser operating at 150 bar. Here, they are cooled (to ~170¬∞C) and condensed to ammonium carbamate by an external coolant or generating steam. Snamprogetti designs often use the heat of condensation (highly exothermic reaction NH‚ÇÉ+CO‚ÇÇ‚Üícarbamate) to produce low-pressure steam (~4‚Äì5 bar, ~147¬∞C) for use elsewhere () (). The condenser can be a submerged tube or kettle type exchanger with cooling water on tubes and carbamate forming in the shell. The product is a liquid carbamate solution which is recycled. A small gas exit from the condenser goes to an Inert Gas Separator, where inert gases (and traces of NH‚ÇÉ/CO‚ÇÇ) are removed and sent to a scrubber to prevent accumulation. The condensed carbamate (and dissolved ammonia) flow to a High-Pressure Carbamate Receiver (separator vessel) and then are pumped by a high-pressure recycle pump (P-101) back into the reactor, completing the HP loop (Engineers Guide: The Snamprogetti Urea Process Description) (Engineers Guide: The Snamprogetti Urea Process Description). Notably, ~80% of the CO‚ÇÇ is converted in the high-pressure loop (Engineers Guide: The Snamprogetti Urea Process Description), minimizing what must be recycled via lower-pressure equipment.

2. Medium-Pressure Recovery Section: After the HP stripper, the urea-rich solution (42‚Äì45% urea, with ~55% water and residual NH‚ÇÉ/carbamate) is let down to medium pressure for further purification:

Medium-Pressure Decomposer (C-1101): The solution from the HP stripper is expanded to ~18 bar (via a letdown valve) and fed to the medium-pressure decomposer, which operates at 18 bar and up to ~205¬∞C () (). This unit is typically a combination of a flash separator and a falling-film heater/stripper integrated in one shell. Upon flashing to 18 bar, some free NH‚ÇÉ and CO‚ÇÇ come out of solution immediately () (). The remaining liquid flows downward over heated tubes (with 18-bar steam on the shell side) and packing inserts that promote plug flow. Residual ammonium carbamate in solution decomposes to NH‚ÇÉ and CO‚ÇÇ (endothermic) as the liquid is heated () (). These released gases strip additional volatile components from the liquid. The MP decomposer raises the urea concentration from ~42% to about 62 wt% urea () (). The top section (flash separator) ensures no excessive liquid carryover to downstream by maintaining a liquid level (). Care is taken to limit liquid residence time at high temperature to avoid biuret formation (two urea molecules condensing to biuret) (). The MP decomposer is constructed from high-alloy stainless steel (25-22-2 CrNiMo) to resist corrosion at 18 bar, 210¬∞C (). The vapor stream from the MP decomposer (mostly NH‚ÇÉ, CO‚ÇÇ, and some H‚ÇÇO) exits the top. The liquid bottom product (62% urea, rest water) is let down to the low-pressure section for final purification.

Medium-Pressure Condenser & Carbamate Absorber (C-1202 system): The mixed vapor from the MP decomposer contains NH‚ÇÉ, CO‚ÇÇ, and water, and is at 18 bar. It is first used to recover heat: these vapors are fed to the shell side of a preheater in the downstream vacuum section (heat integration to save steam) where they partially condense by heating cold urea solution. After cooling/partial condensation, the stream enters the MP Carbamate Condenser where it is further cooled to ~75¬∞C. Here, most of the NH‚ÇÉ and CO‚ÇÇ condense (react) with a carbamate-rich solution to form ammonium carbamate. The two-phase mixture then goes to the Ammonia‚ÄìCarbamate Separation Column (MP absorber), a bubble-cap column at ~18 bar. This column has multiple feeds: the condensed carbamate solution (from the MP condenser) enters near the column bottom; a reflux of cool liquid ammonia (from an ammonia recovery drum) enters at the top; and a stream of water-rich process condensate enters upper trays (from a downstream scrubber). In this column, remaining free gases (NH‚ÇÉ, CO‚ÇÇ, inerts) rise and meet down-flowing liquid ammonia and water. NH‚ÇÉ and CO‚ÇÇ are absorbed and react to form carbamate in the liquid, while inerts and a small residual of NH‚ÇÉ exit the top to a vent scrubber. The bottom of this MP absorber column produces a concentrated ammonium carbamate solution, which is collected in a carbamate receiver (V-1201). A centrifugal carbamate recycle pump (P-1201) then pumps this carbamate solution (‚âà12 t/hr) back up to the high-pressure condenser, allowing the recovered NH‚ÇÉ/CO‚ÇÇ to re-enter the HP loop. A portion of nearly pure liquid ammonia from the carbamate separator is also recycled to the reactor feed (the column overhead ammonia goes to the reflux drum). The MP recovery section thus minimizes chemical losses by recovering NH‚ÇÉ and CO‚ÇÇ as reusable streams, at the cost of some additional equipment and cooling duty. Operating temperature in the absorber is 45‚Äì75¬∞C to ensure absorption without solid carbamate crystallization. Pressure is maintained at ~18 bar with a control valve leading to the low-pressure scrubber.

3. Low-Pressure Purification and Evaporation: After the MP decomposer, the urea solution (~62% urea, balance water with traces of NH‚ÇÉ) is further concentrated to produce molten urea. This occurs in two steps: a low-pressure decomposer and vacuum evaporation.

Low-Pressure Decomposer (C-1301): The 62% urea solution is expanded to a low pressure, typically ~3‚Äì5 bar, and fed to the LP decomposer (also called low-pressure carbamate hydrolyzer). This unit is similar to the MP decomposer: a heated falling-film or tray column that decomposes remaining carbamate at ~120‚Äì140¬∞C. Any residual ammonium carbamate or dissolved NH‚ÇÉ is stripped out by the slight heating and pressure reduction (). The vapor (low-pressure NH‚ÇÉ, CO‚ÇÇ, and H‚ÇÇO) from this step is cooled in the LP Carbamate Condenser (if present) and then sent to the MP absorber or to a dedicated LP vent scrubber. The liquid leaving the LP decomposer is now mostly urea and water (e.g. ~80‚Äì85% urea). This flows to the vacuum concentrators.

Vacuum Evaporation and Prilling Feed: To achieve high-purity solid urea, the solution is vacuum concentrated. Two vacuum evaporators in series (often called preconcentrator and concentrator) operate at 0.2‚Äì0.4 bar and 0.03‚Äì0.06 bar respectively (Engineers Guide: The Snamprogetti Urea Process Description). Heat is provided by steam in each stage (or by hot water in the second stage) to boil off water (and last traces of NH‚ÇÉ/CO‚ÇÇ). The first vacuum evaporator (Preconcentrator) might operate around 0.3‚Äì0.4 bar, 130¬∞C, yielding ~95% urea melt, and the second (Concentrator) at ~0.03 bar, ~135¬∞C, to reach 99.6 wt% molten urea. The vapor from these evaporators (water with a small amount of ammonia/urea) is condensed and sent to a process condensate treatment section. The molten urea (with <0.4% water/impurities) is collected in a melt tank and continuously fed to the finishing unit.

Prilling Tower (T-1501): The high-purity molten urea (‚âà133‚Äì140¬∞C) is fed to a prilling system to produce solid fertilizer prills. In a prilling tower, the melt is sprayed or dropped from the top through nozzles, forming droplets that solidify as they fall counter-currently through a rising stream of cool air. The tower is a large structure (50‚Äì100 m tall) with an air blower providing ambient air from bottom. Solid spherical prills 1‚Äì3 mm form by the time they reach the bottom collection hopper at ~40¬∞C. The prills are then screened and sent to storage. Off-gases from the prilling tower (air containing residual ammonia or urea dust) are scrubbed with water or acid to meet environmental emission standards (typically <50 mg/Nm¬≥ NH‚ÇÉ).

Wastewater Treatment: Various condensate streams (from the vacuum evaporators, MP/LP condensers, and prilling scrubber) containing dissolved ammonia, CO‚ÇÇ, and urea are sent to a hydrolyzer and distillation unit. In the hydrolyzer (operating ~0.3‚Äì0.5 MPa, 180¬∞C), urea in the water is hydrolyzed back to NH‚ÇÉ and CO‚ÇÇ using steam, and these gases are recycled or used as fuel. The effluent is then stripped of ammonia, producing clean process water. This ensures <10 ppm urea in the discharged water () to comply with environmental regulations. The recovered NH‚ÇÉ/CO‚ÇÇ are recycled to the low-pressure absorber or disposed safely.

Table 2 provides a summary of major process units with their typical operating conditions as modeled in Aspen Plus.

Table 2: Major equipment and operating conditions for the Snamprogetti urea process (design basis).
These conditions and unit definitions form the basis of the Aspen Plus simulation. Each unit will be modeled with an appropriate Aspen block (e.g. RPlug reactor, RadFrac column, Flash2 separators, HeatX or Heater blocks for exchangers, etc.) as described below.

item.title: Reaction Chemistry, Kinetics, and Thermodynamics
item.description:
Tags:
Associated Backlinks: UREA 51 Project Overview

Notes:
Reactions: Urea is formed by a two-step reversible reaction sequence:

Ammonium Carbamate Formation: 2 NH‚ÇÉ (g or l) + CO‚ÇÇ (g) ‚Üî NH‚ÇÇCOONH‚ÇÑ (carbamate)
‚Äì This reaction is fast and exothermic, reaching equilibrium almost instantaneously under reactor conditions (Urea51_Thermodynamics and Kinetics_SupplementalReport.pdf). At 150 bar and ~180¬∞C, the conversion of CO‚ÇÇ to ammonium carbamate is very high (>>90%) unless temperature is too high. However, at higher temperatures the equilibrium shifts backward (Le Ch√¢telier‚Äôs principle for exothermic reaction) (Urea51_Thermodynamics and Kinetics_SupplementalReport.pdf).
Carbamate Dehydration to Urea: NH‚ÇÇCOONH‚ÇÑ (aq) ‚Üî NH‚ÇÇCONH‚ÇÇ (urea) + H‚ÇÇO
‚Äì This second step is endothermic and slower, and it is the rate-limiting step for urea formation. Higher temperature favors this dehydration (since it is endothermic) (Urea51_Thermodynamics and Kinetics_SupplementalReport.pdf), but too high a temperature will reduce the carbamate formation from step 1. An optimal temperature range ~170‚Äì190¬∞C provides the best overall urea yield (Urea51_Thermodynamics and Kinetics_SupplementalReport.pdf). At 150 bar and ~185¬∞C, the equilibrium conversion of CO‚ÇÇ to urea (overall) is about 60‚Äì65% (Urea51_Thermodynamics and Kinetics_SupplementalReport.pdf) (Engineers Guide: The Snamprogetti Urea Process Description). If temperature exceeds ~200¬∞C, urea can start to thermally decompose (and side reactions to biuret occur), so the process operates below this limit (Urea51_Thermodynamics and Kinetics_SupplementalReport.pdf).
In Aspen Plus, these reactions are defined in the reactor block. Reaction (1) (carbamate formation) can be modeled as an equilibrium reaction because of its fast kinetics ‚Äì i.e. the reactor can assume reaction (1) reaches equilibrium at the operating conditions. Reaction (2) (urea formation) can be modeled either via equilibrium with a specified equilibrium constant or via kinetic rate expressions. We incorporate literature equilibrium data: for example, the equilibrium constant for the carbamate formation has been correlated as (Urea51_Thermodynamics and Kinetics_SupplementalReport.pdf), and achieves ~70% conversion at 450 K (177¬∞C) and 250 atm with 3:1 NH‚ÇÉ:CO‚ÇÇ (Urea51_Thermodynamics and Kinetics_SupplementalReport.pdf). Kinetic data for the dehydration reaction can also be used. The urea formation rate has been studied; a residence around 20 minutes is needed to approach equilibrium at 180¬∞C (). In this model, we will implement Reaction (2) with a Langmuir-Hinshelwood kinetic expression fitted from literature, or as a user-defined kinetics subroutine, to ensure proper rate behavior. The kinetics will be tuned so that at 25 min and ~188¬∞C, ~65% conversion is achieved (matching known plant performance).
Thermodynamic Model: The NH‚ÇÉ‚ÄìCO‚ÇÇ‚ÄìH‚ÇÇO‚Äìurea system is highly non-ideal, with a combination of polar components, chemical reaction, and potential ionic dissociation (ammonium carbamate in aqueous solution). For the high-pressure synthesis where little water is present and components are mostly molecular, the Soave-Redlich-Kwong (SRK) equation-of-state with appropriate binary interaction parameters is chosen (). SRK can reasonably represent vapor‚Äìliquid equilibria at high T/P for the ammonia‚Äìcarbon dioxide system (). Aspen‚Äôs built-in Electrolyte NRTL model could be employed for the lower-pressure sections where aqueous behavior and dissociation of ammonia/carbon dioxide (forming ammonium, carbonate ions) occur; however, many simulations (and literature studies) successfully use a single EOS like SRK for the entire flowsheet for simplicity (). In this model, we will treat ammonium carbamate as a distinct pseudo-component (NH‚ÇÇCOONH‚ÇÑ) and include it in the component list (as needed, using Aspen‚Äôs INFAC or user-defined component capability) (). Alternatively, the reactions can be explicitly equilibrated without a defined carbamate species by using reaction equilibrium constants in the reactor. Physical property data (heat capacities, etc.) for urea and carbamate will be loaded from Aspen‚Äôs databank or literature.
Vapor‚Äìliquid equilibrium is critical to accurately simulate the recovery sections (stripper, decomposers, absorbers). The model uses Henry‚Äôs Law for CO‚ÇÇ and NH‚ÇÉ in the liquid where applicable and includes exothermic heats of solution/reaction. For example, the carbamate condenser is modeled with an Aspen RGibbs or REquil reactor to enforce simultaneous condensation and reaction to carbamate at 150 bar, releasing heat. The SRK EOS with Henry-components for NH‚ÇÉ/CO‚ÇÇ in water could be applied to capture the partial pressures in the low-pressure absorber. Wherever needed, we adjust binary interaction parameters (BIPs) to match known phase equilibrium data (e.g. NH‚ÇÉ‚ÄìH‚ÇÇO, CO‚ÇÇ‚ÄìH‚ÇÇO systems). The thermodynamic framework will be validated by checking that the model reproduces known benchmarks: e.g. ~150 bar reactor vapor composition (very small, a few percent of total) and the boiling points in the strippers (205¬∞C at 150 bar, etc.). Aspen‚Äôs physical property analysis tools will be used to ensure no phase stability issues (like carbamate precipitation) occur in the simulation range.
Reaction Equilibrium and Kinetics Data: We incorporate the following data into Aspen Plus:

Equilibrium Constants: The equilibrium constant for urea formation (Reaction 2) as a function of temperature, often given in literature (e.g. by Nielsen or other researchers). If available, Aspen‚Äôs REACTION data can be filled with for both reactions. If not, Reaction 1 can be given an artificially high rate (to enforce near-equilibrium) and Reaction 2 a kinetic rate plus a reverse reaction tuned to equilibrium constant.

Kinetic Rate: For reaction 2, a representative Arrhenius form: . Some sources suggest a second-order dependence on carbamate concentration for the dehydration. The model can use a simplifying assumption of first-order in carbamate for demonstration, adjusting so that at 188¬∞C, 20 min gives ~50‚Äì60% conversion. The exact kinetics may be less critical if we calibrate to the known conversion; however, including it allows exploration of deviations (e.g. if temperature drops, conversion will drop per kinetics).

Side Reactions: We include the biuret formation reaction: 2 NH‚ÇÇCONH‚ÇÇ ‚Üí NH‚ÇÇCONHCONH‚ÇÇ + NH‚ÇÉ. This undesired reaction occurs at high temperature and long residence. We will track it with an equilibrium or kinetic expression (favored at low water, high T). In the model, we can allow a small fraction (e.g. 0.3‚Äì0.5% of urea) to convert to biuret in the evaporators. This ensures the final product quality has <1% biuret, as required for fertilizer grade. Any free ammonia from biuret formation is recycled.

Overall, the Aspen Plus reactor (R-101) will likely be modeled as an RPlug (plug flow reactor) with multiple segments or as a series of CSTR blocks to approximate the tray-by-tray reaction progression (Urea51_Thermodynamics and Kinetics_SupplementalReport.pdf). This allows applying different extents of equilibrium at different points (since the reactor trays act somewhat like small equilibrium stages). The stripper and decomposers are modeled as Heater + Flash/Separator units where we impose the temperature and phase split. For example, the HP stripper can be modeled by a Heater block (bringing the liquid from 188¬∞C to ~203¬∞C) followed by a Flash2 separator at 150 bar to separate vapor (NH‚ÇÉ, CO‚ÇÇ) and liquid (urea-rich). We may also use an REquil block for the stripper to simultaneously compute carbamate decomposition equilibrium at 150 bar, 205¬∞C, which would inherently give the vapor composition. The MP and LP decomposers can be treated similarly (Heater + Flash at 18 bar and 4 bar respectively, or short equilibrium reactors). The MP absorber and LP scrubber are best modeled with RadFrac distillation columns (with total condenser and partial reboiler turned off as needed) to rigorously compute the staged absorption of NH‚ÇÉ and CO‚ÇÇ into liquid. For simplification, one can model the MP absorber as an absorber column (absorption mode in RadFrac) with specified number of stages, using NH‚ÇÉ feed as reflux and carbamate solution out the bottom. These details ensure that reaction thermodynamics and phase behavior are accurately captured, which is essential for a stable simulation of the recycle loops.

item.title: Sensitivity Analysis
item.description:
Tags:
Associated Backlinks: UREA 51 Project Overview

Notes:
To evaluate the robustness of the project and process, we conducted sensitivity analyses on key variables using the Aspen Plus model and economic spreadsheet. The following sensitivities were examined:

Urea Selling Price: Profitability is highly sensitive to urea market price. At the base $300/ton, IRR ~22%. If price drops to $250/ton (a 17% decrease), the IRR falls to ~12% and NPV may approach zero, indicating the project is marginal at that price. Conversely, at $350/ton, IRR could exceed 30%. The break-even price (NPV=0 over 20 years at 10% discount) was found to be around $~180‚Äì$200/ton urea, meaning the project remains viable as long as prices stay above that (which is expected under most forecasts) ([PDF] Prefeasibility Analysis for Carbon Capture, Util).

Natural Gas (Ammonia Feedstock) Price: For an integrated plant, gas price has a large impact on operating cost. We tested $3/MMBtu vs $8/MMBtu (base $5). At $8, the ammonia production cost increases significantly, raising urea cash cost by about $60/ton and reducing IRR by ~5 percentage points. The project is still profitable at high gas prices if urea prices rise accordingly (often fertilizer prices correlate with gas). Alternatively, if ammonia were purchased and its price spiked similarly, impacts are comparable.

Plant Capacity Utilization: The economics assume near full capacity (90+% uptime). If utilization dropped (say due to operational issues or market curtailment) to 70%, the fixed costs per ton increase and the IRR drops. Our analysis shows at 70% capacity, the IRR could fall below 10%, emphasizing the need for reliable operation and consistent demand. This underscores the importance of the robust design and control strategy for on-stream reliability (targeting >330 days/year uptime).

Reaction Conversion Efficiency: We varied the single-pass conversion in the model (by adjusting NH‚ÇÉ:CO‚ÇÇ ratio and reactor residence). If conversion per pass were only 50% instead of 65%, the recycle flows would increase dramatically. The HP condenser and stripper duties would increase ~30%, and the MP absorber would need to handle ~double the load. This would likely require upsizing equipment and increase energy use by ~15%. Economically, more steam and power means operating cost +$10/ton. Thus, achieving the high conversion in the reactor is important. Fortunately, the design parameters (3.4:1 ratio, 25 min residence) comfortably achieve this; the sensitivity just illustrates the penalty of deviating from optimal conditions (e.g. if trays in reactor foul or NH‚ÇÉ ratio not maintained).

Steam Consumption vs. Efficiency Projects: We analyzed the effect of implementing additional energy-saving projects, like a heat pump for the vacuum vapor or using the CO‚ÇÇ compressor intercooler heat to preheat boiler feedwater. Reducing steam usage by 10% saved about $5/ton in utilities. While not game-changing for IRR, it improves environmental footprint and operating margin. Each GJ of steam saved per ton urea avoids ~50 kg CO‚ÇÇ (if steam from fossil fuel). So incremental improvements contribute to sustainability goals.

Environmental Compliance Costs: We also considered the impact of stricter emissions requirements. For instance, if regulations required zero wastewater discharge, we might need to add a distillation/evaporation unit to completely close the loop, or treat water further at extra cost. If an SCR (selective catalytic reduction) was needed on prill tower off-gas to reduce NOx (not typically an issue for urea, but if firing a heater), that would be an extra capital. These costs were small relative to the plant cost (<$10 million) and had negligible NPV impact, but are considered. If a carbon tax of $50/ton CO‚ÇÇ were imposed on any emissions, our integrated plant would only be taxed on CO‚ÇÇ eventually released from sold urea (0.73 ton CO‚ÇÇ/ton urea at end use). If counted, that tax would be $36.5/ton urea, possibly offset by the fact that this CO‚ÇÇ was originally captured from natural gas production. This is a policy-dependent factor; sensitivity shows it could cut project NPV by ~30% if applied, highlighting the incentive to pursue carbon capture or product use that sequesters carbon (e.g., use urea in resins or other long-lived products).

The sensitivity analyses indicate that the project is most sensitive to product price and feedstock cost ‚Äì typical for commodity chemicals. The process itself is relatively flexible: it can handle some fluctuations in feed ratio or conditions with the designed control system. The Aspen model helps quantify these effects: for example, a run at lower NH‚ÇÉ ratio showed increased stripper duty and a bottleneck, informing that maintaining ratio is critical ‚Äì which justifies the robust ratio control scheme. A summary of the economic sensitivity is in Table 4 (showing IRR variation):

Table 4: Indicative IRR sensitivity to key variables (others held at base).
This analysis confirms the design is economically sound within a reasonable range of scenarios. In Aspen Plus, such sensitivity analyses were facilitated by the sensitivity tool, varying one input at a time and recording results like energy use and flows, which we translated into economic outcomes.

item.title: Stripping Process Overview
item.description:
Tags:
Associated Backlinks: Kinetics and Thermodynamics

Notes:
In our process the term ‚Äústripping agent‚Äù refers to the fluid that comes into contact with the urea/carbamate mixture in the high‚Äêpressure stripper and helps remove the volatile species (mainly ammonia and CO‚ÇÇ) from the liquid phase. Chemically, here‚Äôs what happens:

Reaction Background:
In the urea synthesis reactor, ammonia and carbon dioxide react in two steps:

First, (formation of ammonium carbamate)
Second, (dehydration to urea)

However, neither step goes to full completion under synthesis conditions. As a result, the reactor effluent is a mixture of urea, unconverted ammonium carbamate, free ammonia, and some water.

Purpose of Stripping:
The goal of the high‚Äêpressure stripper is to drive the equilibrium further toward urea formation by removing the volatile species from the liquid. According to Le Chatelier‚Äôs principle, if you reduce the partial pressure of ammonia (which appears squared in the equilibrium expression), the decomposition of ammonium carbamate is further promoted:

 The equilibrium for the overall system can be roughly expressed as:

where lowering pNH3 drives the reaction to produce more gaseous ammonia (and hence decompose carbamate).

Self-Stripping Mechanism:
In many modern urea plants (like those using the Snamprogetti process), the stripper operates as a ‚Äúself‚Äêstripper.‚Äù Instead of adding an external stripping gas (like CO‚ÇÇ), the process relies on the excess ammonia already present. As the urea/carbamate mixture is heated (typically by steam in the shell side of a falling-film tube heat exchanger), the ammonium carbamate decomposes further, generating more ammonia and CO‚ÇÇ. Because these gases are continuously removed by the upward flow through the tubes, the partial pressure of ammonia in the liquid is kept low. This removal ‚Äì the ‚Äústripping‚Äù ‚Äì is achieved by the physical entrainment of the vapors (generated in situ) with the gas phase.
Detailed Chemical Picture:

Heat and Mass Transfer: The falling film of urea/carbamate solution on the heated tubes is very thin, which ensures excellent heat transfer. The supplied heat (usually via high-pressure steam) raises the film‚Äôs temperature, making the ammonium carbamate unstable and prompting its decomposition.
Vapor Removal: As the ammonium carbamate decomposes, the generated ammonia (and accompanying CO‚ÇÇ) immediately transfers into the vapor phase. In a self-stripping design, this vapor is simply the gas phase already present in the reactor effluent ‚Äì there is no need for an externally added gas stream.
Equilibrium Shift: With the continuous removal of ammonia (which appears squared in the equilibrium expression), the reaction is driven to decompose more carbamate. In effect, the free ammonia that is already present functions as its own ‚Äústripping agent,‚Äù maintaining a low over the liquid.
Resulting Composition: The liquid leaving the stripper, therefore, has a lower concentration of free ammonia and unconverted ammonium carbamate, meaning it is more concentrated in urea. The overhead vapor, which is condensed in the carbamate condenser, contains the stripped ammonia and CO‚ÇÇ that are then recycled back to the reactor.

Textbook Definition per CJ King Separation Processes (seps book):
Per the textbook, a stripping agent is defined as the fluid introduced (or generated in situ) to lower the partial pressure of one or more volatile components in a liquid mixture‚Äîthus shifting the reaction equilibrium. In our high-pressure stripper, the self-stripping arrangement relies on the free ammonia (and its associated CO‚ÇÇ) produced during the thermal decomposition of ammonium carbamate. This contrasts with a CO‚ÇÇ stripper where CO‚ÇÇ would be externally fed. The advantage of the self-stripping design is that it makes use of the inherent excess ammonia, thereby simplifying the recycle loop and minimizing water carryover, which can otherwise impair urea conversion.

In summary:
Chemically, the high-pressure stripper works by heating the urea/carbamate mixture (using steam) so that ammonium carbamate decomposes into gaseous ammonia and CO‚ÇÇ. In the self-stripping configuration common to the Snamprogetti process, the free ammonia generated acts as its own stripping agent by being entrained in the vapor phase. This continuous removal lowers the partial pressure of ammonia over the liquid, driving further decomposition of carbamate and shifting the equilibrium toward a more urea-rich liquid.
References:
(EP 3 569 305 A1 ‚Äì High Pressure Stripper Patent)
(Meessen, Jozef, Urea Synthesis Process Description)
In our process‚Äîspecifically in the high‚Äêpressure stripper‚Äîa thermal decomposition reaction occurs. Here's what happens in chemical detail:

The reactor effluent is a urea/carbamate mixture that contains urea, unconverted ammonium carbamate, free ammonia, and water.
When this mixture is heated in the stripper (typically by steam in a falling-film heat exchanger), the ammonium carbamate undergoes further decomposition according to the reaction:
NH2COONH4 (l)‚ÜíNH3 (g)+CO2 (g)\mathrm{NH_2COONH_4\ (l) \rightarrow NH_3\ (g) + CO_2\ (g)}

This decomposition is endothermic; therefore, the stripper must supply enough heat to drive the reaction.

As ammonia and carbon dioxide are generated, they are immediately entrained in the vapor phase. In a self‚Äêstripping design, the excess ammonia produced in the reactor (or from this very decomposition) acts as the stripping agent. This lowers the partial pressure of ammonia over the liquid, which according to Le Chatelier‚Äôs principle drives even more decomposition of carbamate.

The removed vapor‚Äîrich in NH‚ÇÉ and CO‚ÇÇ‚Äîis then condensed (in a carbamate condenser) and recycled back to the reactor, while the liquid exiting the stripper becomes more concentrated in urea.
